headline: Media coverage of Mollie Tibbetts' murder

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hi, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Pam Bondi, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and she skateboards in a salad bowl, Dana Perino -- "The Five." On MSNBC -- a network -- Tuesday, a guest mocked Fox News for devoting time to the murder of Mollie Tibbetts:

utterances.speaker: CHRISTINA GREER, FORDHAM UNIVERSITY
utterances.sentences: I'm sure we'll hear what he has to say about this at his rally. But Fox News is talking about, you know, a girl in Iowa and not this, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right, a girl in Iowa. She's right. And a girl in Iowa murdered pales in importance when compared to tax evasion, because if you talk about Mollie, you can't talk about the things that the media thinks is important. To the press, your sorrow over a young woman's death is got to be political. And that hush money among adults is more harmful to society than a brutal killing.  The media is obsessed with Manafort and Cohen -- victimless, gotcha crimes. But for most Americans, we know a true victim when we see her. It ain't the IRS or Stormy. And so we're smeared for thinking murder matters more than a bad 1040. So maybe we need to help the media find equivalencies. Let me ask you dear media: How many Mollies is a Mike Cohen worth? The answer: As many as it takes to undo an election and the facts be damned. On Sunday, this story took off on Twitter: ICE had nabbed a guy on the way to the hospital with his pregnant wife. It was perfect media fodder, until we later found out the dad was a murder suspect, so mysteriously, that story went away. Or how about the Nazi death camp guard living in Queens? Obama's White House knew about him but ignored it even as the Nazi's Jewish neighbors called him out. Then we had an election and Trump, using ICE, deported him. So without ICE, we'd have at least one Nazi on the loose.  If this is the first time you've heard of these stories, I get it. These days, you stick to the story you want to tell, which is why to some, Mollie Tibbetts is just some girl in Iowa.   To be fair, I want to run this apology from the Fordham Professor Christine Greer who said -- apologized on twitter. It's a non-apology, but let's run it anyway. She said, yesterday, I've said something flippant that was unintended. Mollie Tibbetts was a promising young woman who lost her life. My hope is that her family will find peace and justice. And that her murder is not used to justify a discriminatory immigration policy. Dana, from a public relations perspective, she probably could have stopped that apology when it mattered.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's one of my things I can't stand about, this -- like backhanded apology. If somebody says, I've never agreed with her in my entire life, but she had a good point there. They don't want to sully themselves with that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Whenever you see a but coming, it's not an apology.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's not. You just put a period.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Or an, and, and then say something more kind. The abolish ICE bumper sticker leaves no room for complexity or nuance. And so, you have a situation where Democrats are having to answer questions. Like, are you for abolishing ICE? Are you for abolishing ICE? And most of them are like, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm not for abolishing ICE. But because there are some left-wing folks out there that really want to try to get a rise out of people, and probably believe that we should abolish ICE, they have backed a lot of Democrats into a corner on this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Pam, welcome to the show, good to see you.

utterances.speaker: PAM BONDI, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Thank you. You, too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The -- CNN and MSNBC, they didn't take the arraignment for the suspect because they've believed that's not news, I guess. He has a private attorney. I was wondering who is paying for that. But also, how did he get through? I've read different stories. Did he -- did they do e- verify on him? Did he have a fake ID?

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: Yeah. It's saying that -- like the farm owner says that he went through e-verify. He turned over completely cooperate to turn over all the documents. And then DHS, NHL, ICE, they're looking at it to see what happened with e-verify. This guy has been in the country forever. And he murdered a beautiful young girl. From being in a courtroom my entire career, that's who everybody in this country should be focusing on, that victim's parents, her family. Can you imagine what they're going through?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, I know, it's unimaginable. And we've talked about families being separated. That's separation. I want to run, Juan, for you, some tapes from Elizabeth Warren. She was talking about this case, lamenting the crime, but then inserting a but.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, D-MASS.
utterances.sentences: I'm so sorry for the family here. And I know this is hard, not only for the family, but for the people in her community, the people throughout Iowa. But, one of the things we have to remember is we need an immigration system that is effective, that focuses on where real problems are.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, Juan, I guess this isn't a real problem that this young woman was murdered?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: No. That's -- I mean, you set it up as so prejudicial to our audience here. I mean, the clear fact of what happened is just horrible to this young woman. But it's also reminds me of the case, Steinle case, where her brother, Brad, came forward and said that he thought Trump was sensationalizing the death of a beautiful young woman. Why would her brother, why would Kate Steinle's brother say that? Because what you see is that people use this for their own purpose. And Trump's case, he's using this to distract and to deceive people in terms of the big news of the day, which is about the Michael Cohen plea deal, about Paul Manafort being convicted. I mean, at this point, you have the president's personal lawyer, his campaign chairman, his national security advisor, all convicted felons. And, oh, no, instead, we want to talk about a murder. Well, there're lots of murders in America. There's a lower rate of violent crime among illegal immigrants and immigrants than there is among native- born Americans.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Guess what? There're some people who say let's not talk about Trump because it's bad news. Like, Trump -- let's talk about this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The point is essential, like there may be more people that are killed texting while driving. So, let's not pay attention to drunk driving. We can exactly tackle both, Juan.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Juan -- I think Juan wants to distract from.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I just want talk about the news of the day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Which we did and we are.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And we're already talking about the Cohen and Manafort case in the B block. Now we're leading the show with this story. So, it seems like you're the one that's trying to distract.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No. Well, we're leading with the story about one woman's death.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You just sounded like the professor. There's some one woman.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Just one woman.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Just a girl in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The presidency of the United States, Jesse, is imperiled by these decisions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, according to you. But you know who's really imperiled? Mollie. Now let me just say something, what happened here was horrible and my heart goes out to the family. There's two levels to the story, I think. One, how many dead people are we going to tolerate in this country without solving the immigration problem? We have to have stricter borders. We can't have sanctuary. And we have to do something where you have to be able to verify the people that are in here. Now, on the other hand, the media does not report these stories honestly. And if you look at this one and the other ones that you've mentioned up there, they're misinforming the audience. They're not informing. I looked at that story about the arrest, about the guy driving his wife. And you had to read six paragraphs down to find out that he was wanted for a homicide beef. Now, that would seem like something that would lead and actually be in the headline, but they don't - - they don't inform their viewers. And they're doing the same thing. Now that it's found out that this person is allegedly here illegally, this has now dropped off the top row of a lot of cable news networks and a lot of newspapers. And it's a shame because the American people need to understand the facts about these things so they can elect politicians who can then solve problems.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, let me just say, I don't think there's any correlation between illegal immigration and violent crime in our country, but you make that connection. I don't think it's fair. To me, you know, what's interesting is if there was a mass murderer yesterday, all you guys would be saying, you know, this is not the time to talk about gun control. Let's not do that. That's what the right says. So, here I say, today, and you have one woman who was sadly, tragically killed in Iowa, and you guys want to start talking about immigration.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What happens in this country is that there's tragic events, and then politicians try to lead and try to have solutions. Just like if there was a school shooting, Democrats want to do gun control. Or if there's a hurricane, Democrats want to talk about climate change. I don't blame either side for doing it. That's what politicians do.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, you do. In fact, you sit here and say this is not the time to talk about gun control in the aftermath of a mass murder, but now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not every mass murder.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think the lesson here is we have a broken system that needs fixing. A fix-them, is a like to call.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, a fix-them. It needs to be fixed. I guess they claimed that they were wrong. He didn't get e-verify. That's what I'm learning.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's a different type of system is that what you verify. One thing about -- there's -- Lamar Smith has a legislation in front of congress right now, his e-verify system would add that you would be notified if your social security number was put through the system so that you could say, wait, hold on, like, I'm actually here. My social security number is being used.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: And that's why e-verify should be mandatory. And, you know, as a prosecutor, when you're in the courtroom every day for years dealing with victims, you look at -- the only way you can cope is looking at it one victim at a time, and how can we prevent more young girls, boys from being murdered? And that's why this is an important dialogue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Excellent. OK, we've got to move on. Donald Trump hammering his former attorney, Michael Cohen, I wonder why? New reaction from the president, next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: After blasting his former attorney on twitter, President Trump now saying he did not order Michael Cohen to make hush money payments.

utterances.speaker: AINSLEY EARHARDT, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: Did you know about the payments?

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Later on I knew. Later on. But you have to understand is, like, what he did, and they weren't taken out of campaign finance. That's a big thing. That's a much bigger thing. Did they come out of the campaign? They didn't come out of the campaign. They came from me. It's not even a campaign violation. If you look at President Obama, he had a massive campaign violation, but he had a different attorney general and they viewed it a lot different.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And that exclusive interview airs tomorrow on Fox & Friends. Meanwhile, Cohen's lawyer, longtime Clinton ally, Lanny Davis, is on a media blitz making new allegations against the President, while also trying to raise money for his client's legal fees.

utterances.speaker: LANNY DAVIS, MICHAEL COHEN'S ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: He directed Mr. Cohen to make those hush money payments is a federal crime. And if Michael Cohen, with the prosecutors in New York agreeing, admitted to that, then certainly, Donald Trump is guilty of the same crime. Mr. Cohen has knowledge on certain subjects that should be of interest to the special counsel. And is more than happy to tell the special counsel all that he knows.  He needs help for himself and his family, and the Michael Cohen truthfund.com go to site is for the American people who want to help.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. More go-fund-me pages. All right, Juan, you've seem like you've been chomping at the bit to tackle this issue. Let it rip.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I mean, I don't want to rip on anything. I just think it's a sad day, and you've got to wonder what's going on when the president is out there saying that Paul Manafort is a brave man, then it raises the question, oh, so he thinks Paul Manafort, who just, you know, been convicted on eight counts and faces 80 years in jail, a convicted felon, all of a sudden, he's a brave man. So, is he thinking about pardoning this man? Oh, because it's politically convenient and he knows Paul Manafort who was his campaign. And then you think, oh, he's out there damning Michael Cohen because he thinks Cohen may have additional facts that could be problematic for this president. It looks so awful that the President of the United States is in this position, and has put himself in this position, and surrounded himself, Jesse, I do this just to tease you, with the very best people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Only the best.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Only the best.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Paul and Michael. Dana, I think when he was saying he's brave, he meant that -- he's looking at, probably, the rest of his life in prison, and he's not going to make up some phony story to satisfy prosecutors out of thin air. I think that's what he was talking about.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, thank you for helping with that. This is how I might have said it, which is I appreciated what he did for me on my campaign. I feel bad for his family that they're going through this. He has been convicted by a jury of his peers under our judicial system, and he's going to have to pay the price for that. Moving on. Like, you don't need to try to make him a synthetic character. He was stealing from the American people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: When I do something wrong, I'm going to have you write my tweets.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Which could be any day now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Can I represent you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No. You'll be my.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Are you kidding? I would be a tiger for you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What's so funny because Lanny was the one with the Clinton team that set up this dossier in motion, and then got Cohen on the radar and that's when everybody started looking into him -- you know, hasn't been paying his taxes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm still in that world of I don't care. I mean, this stuff happened before Trump took office, so it's not an impeachable offense. You can't indict a sitting president. So why is this happening? It's just a mess with the guy. That's all this is. This is all about the election and undoing an election, and anger. It's really selective prosecution because there are people like this in Hillary's orbit. You can believe that for a fact.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She had been on the hook is she had won

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, exactly. I mean, how did she pay for that dossier? I don't know. Did she declare it? (INAUDIBLE) I don't know. What about Harvey Weinstein? If she had won, would the Me Too -- would we have known about Harvey Weinstein? Of course not. All of that stuff would have been buried. So let's face it. We're not dealing with angels. But I've moved beyond that. I don't care if they're not angels. I don't care about the lawyers. Trump is not the greatest husband, you know. Stormy has really given porn stars a bad name. She -- when you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's such a good name to.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The only thing she's doing is she's just mad she didn't get more money out of a deal that she's now reneging on.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: Right, agree there about giving porn stars a bad name. But in the real world, this happens all the time, OK? CEO's, millionaires, they get extorted all the time. All the time. And they often -- I've been called about it, what do I do? And I say report it to the police. Most of them don't want to report it. So what's their next option? Go to a civil lawyer. And that's what a non-lawyer, Donald Trump did. He went to an attorney. He could have given her cash. He could have paid her off. He went to an attorney and said fix this legally. And this is on Michael Cohen. This is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Legally?

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: Sure. Sure, you can sign a nondisclosure. You can sign -- this happens all the time in the real business world. You can sign a nondisclosure. You can make a payment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: With campaign money?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's the problem.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: No, but that's it. But.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's the problem.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: . it's where the money came from. That is on the lawyer. A bad lawyer does not equal.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: . that's what he went to his lawyer.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But we have a tape, Pam. A tape in which the president is discussing this with Michael Cohen.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: And Cohen should have told him you cannot use campaign funds.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They thought you were on one of those tapes, didn't they?

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: Isn't it funny? So I listened to it and they've said it was inaudible and I've said, he said Pam. I've heard that, it was Pam. I don't think it's me because I didn't do anything in South Carolina.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It was Pam Dauber from Mork and Mindy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think what the president is saying is that these were personal funds that he used to, I guess, pass through a lawyer to have this woman sign an NDA, and it was a personal matter. Maybe it did affect the campaign, but the primary reason was to settle it to not cause any harm to the marriage, or not to cause any bad publicity, or just to get it out of the way because she'd been asking for money for quite some time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: If it turns out that it is from his own personal checkbook and it didn't go through the campaign, then maybe he's got a point. But I don't see how the prosecutors could have gotten Cohen to plead guilty for something if it was not actually campaign money.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And what about the money for the National Enquirer? That came - - that was from the National Enquirer to, I think, Karen McDougal who is the Playboy model.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Did you think -- because, you know, Andrew McCarthy had a great piece in the National Review.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow. We've been quoting him all week.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Where he was saying -- probably bringing the pain on these other tax charges and saying you're looking at a lot of time, you know. Why don't you plead to these lesser kind of campaign violations.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Possibly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's a thinner case.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Possible. But then, also, and I don't know anything about this one either, but now Cohen has another subpoena.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: . about the Trump foundation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, I mean, he's in a situation where he's in a downward spiral.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, they're going after him big time. And I think I agree with Greg. It's to avenge Hillary's loss and to bring a lot of heartbreak on the president.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: And he's useful to the criminal prosecution, unless they have other credible evidence because he's told so many stories.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, his credibility is shot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: One thing to note, for the longest time we've been saying Trump has a thin skin. He's got a pretty thick hide to do his job while this is going on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, that's tough. Tough day. More tough days ahead, I'm sure. The anti-Trump media ramping up impeachment talk, again, after these developments. That's ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The media revs up the push to impeach President Trump, this follows Michael Cohen's guilty plea. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You now have the President of the United States accused of committing a federal crime. The way a functional Washington would work is that congress -- there's a process here. The judiciary committee and the House of Representatives will begin to look to see if there's enough evidence to start investigating and drawing up articles of impeachment.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Should the president be more worried about impeachment than before because of what have happened today?

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Are we in impeachment territory here?

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Today, the Trump presidency took a giant step toward impeachment.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, the question is, is the media sort of salivating, especially left-wing media, or is there justification for this, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I think -- I feel that they're hoping that this story can keep going because there's not that much else actually going on in August. They would like to see impeachment. Guess who doesn't want to see impeachment talk? Pelosi, Schumer, like leading Democrats who are saying please do not try to suggest this because you will overplay your hand. And if you want to encourage Republicans to get out and vote in the midterms, you will keep on this nonsense about impeachment. I saw one Democrat suggest forget impeachment, go for the indictment, even though there's this -- you can't indict a sitting president. Some people think that that is an open question that should be taken to the Supreme Court. Regardless, I think, impeachment, it's going to be impossible for them to stop talking about it completely, but I think maybe there'll be a bat signal to all the Democrats to cool it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, Pam, you're the lawyer sitting here with us today, so tell us. Can you indict a sitting president? And, if not, is impeachment a legitimate alternative?

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: If it's a legitimate case, of course. And that's probably what Mueller is looking in putting together now, an impeachment memo, which congress.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Or not.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: . would love. Or possibly, right. But I don't feel they have enough to do it. We all know it's super high standard. You know, you've got to have a majority of the house, and then it goes to the senate. Two- thirds. It's not going to happen. And because of what I said earlier, you know, you cannot link the president back to this. First of all, it has nothing to do with Russia. You've got some guy, Michael Cohen, saying I'd take a bullet for Trump. Then next, he's going after the President of the United States. So he has zero credibility. They would have to have credible, substantial, independent information to corroborate anything Cohen says. I think, like you said, for Mueller to even write an impeachment memo, it's just not there. And they just can't go forward with it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But, Jesse, yesterday in court, Cohen said that Trump instructed him to violate the law, and Cohen said this publicly in open court, right? And, apparently, then the question becomes, is the president an unindicted coconspirator, should, at least, the congress be looking at this and saying, gee, the president looks to have been named as having committed a felony?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's their prerogative. They can look at whatever they want to look at. I don't know if I trust Michael Cohen that much. He's facing a lot of hard time. And it's a he said-he said. So let the chips fall where they will. Two-thirds of the senate -- all this is, is a talking point for the Democrats. And they do win the house, there may be a move to impeach. And to say, you know, we're going to run in 2020 against an impeached incumbent gives the Democrats some, you know, political credibility there. And it's harmful to the president, I think, politically to be impeached. But, you know, it will also, maybe, hurt the economy a little bit and undermine his credibility as the commander-in-chief when he goes abroad. But, I just don't see it happening. Independents don't believe this is a high crime. Republicans, obviously, don't believe this is an impeachable offense. I don't think there's an appetite in the country for this. The story is probably going to fizzle out in a few days. And the Democrats, with Maxine Waters, are going to have a hard time keeping lid on these feisty, you know, far left people on the far left and it's going to be a real headache for the leadership, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The media can't stop talking about impeachment. It is their jasper. And I do believe it shows they can't even think things through. It's like if you actually do impeach Trump, you will have Mike Pence, a guy who was so conservative. He won't be alone with his wife. So I'm joking, of course.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm joking. But anyway, he's a -- he makes Trump look like Che Guevara. And if -- let's say you get your magical dream of impeachment, you will radicalize a lot of Americans who will feel that you have stolen - - stolen your -- their votes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And if you think that the America thinks you are fake news now, God knows what they're going to think of you then. I mean that they will - - I don't even want to talk about it. And also, lastly, we have now spent 21 minutes on this topic, Juan. We only spent 10 minutes on Mollie Tibbetts. So to your point, you were incorrect.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I think the top of the show was the distraction.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No actually again, do you actually --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Well wait, I see the eBlock because --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- Mollie Tibbetts is not a distraction.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And more people come into this show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: If you look at the ratings, in the middle of the show because they're coming home from work.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So right now they're getting more news.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Escaping a forest fire.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. OK. Just checking.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That looked like on an (INAUDIBLE) like at the end of time, you know one of those novel?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Let's get to Pam.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: I've got one, Officers Matthew Suddeth and Cory Glasscock in Alabama. If we could run the video went above and beyond. These officers look at this running into a burning home without waiting on firefighters. Geez. So they've break the window and there's the clip there, they're not in the proper gear, they're running into harm's way instead of away. They take -- look at this grabbing this woman, taking her to safety and that's what all our great men and women do in uniform every single day. They run into harm's way instead of away from it. And that's why it's so very important when you see a police officer, appreciate what they do and their spouses and their families. There's no ordinary day for a police officer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly. All right.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.sentences: Well that was fun.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It was fun. So set your DVRs, never miss an episode of THE FIVE. There's no rhyme to share, and eat it by bear (ph). Up next, Bret there. Hey Bret.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Hi Greg. Thanks. I'm good. Legal obstacles and options facing President Trump. The confession of an illegal immigrant to the murder of an Iowa college co- ed puts immigration back on the front burner. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc. You may not alter or remove any trademark, copyright or other notice from copies of the content.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hi, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Pam Bondi, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and she skateboards in a salad bowl, Dana Perino -- "The Five."

utterances.speaker: On MSNBC -- a network -- Tuesday, a guest mocked Fox News for devoting time to the murder of Mollie Tibbetts
CHRISTINA GREER, FORDHAM UNIVERSITY
utterances.utterance: I'm sure we'll hear what he has to say about this at his rally. But Fox News is talking about, you know, a girl in Iowa and not this, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right, a girl in Iowa. She's right. And a girl in Iowa murdered pales in importance when compared to tax evasion, because if you talk about Mollie, you can't talk about the things that the media thinks is important. To the press, your sorrow over a young woman's death is got to be political. And that hush money among adults is more harmful to society than a brutal killing. The media is obsessed with Manafort and Cohen -- victimless, gotcha crimes. But for most Americans, we know a true victim when we see her. It ain't the IRS or Stormy. And so we're smeared for thinking murder matters more than a bad 1040. So maybe we need to help the media find equivalencies. Let me ask you dear media: How many Mollies is a Mike Cohen worth? The answer: As many as it takes to undo an election and the facts be damned.

utterances.speaker: On Sunday, this story took off on Twitter
utterances.utterance: ICE had nabbed a guy on the way to the hospital with his pregnant wife. It was perfect media fodder, until we later found out the dad was a murder suspect, so mysteriously, that story went away. Or how about the Nazi death camp guard living in Queens? Obama's White House knew about him but ignored it even as the Nazi's Jewish neighbors called him out. Then we had an election and Trump, using ICE, deported him. So without ICE, we'd have at least one Nazi on the loose. If this is the first time you've heard of these stories, I get it. These days, you stick to the story you want to tell, which is why to some, Mollie Tibbetts is just some girl in Iowa. To be fair, I want to run this apology from the Fordham Professor Christine Greer who said -- apologized on twitter. It's a non-apology, but let's run it anyway. She said, yesterday, I've said something flippant that was unintended. Mollie Tibbetts was a promising young woman who lost her life. My hope is that her family will find peace and justice. And that her murder is not used to justify a discriminatory immigration policy. Dana, from a public relations perspective, she probably could have stopped that apology when it mattered.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's one of my things I can't stand about, this -- like backhanded apology. If somebody says, I've never agreed with her in my entire life, but she had a good point there. They don't want to sully themselves with that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Whenever you see a but coming, it's not an apology.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not. You just put a period.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Or an, and, and then say something more kind. The abolish ICE bumper sticker leaves no room for complexity or nuance. And so, you have a situation where Democrats are having to answer questions. Like, are you for abolishing ICE? Are you for abolishing ICE? And most of them are like, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm not for abolishing ICE. But because there are some left-wing folks out there that really want to try to get a rise out of people, and probably believe that we should abolish ICE, they have backed a lot of Democrats into a corner on this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Pam, welcome to the show, good to see you.

utterances.speaker: PAM BONDI, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Thank you. You, too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The -- CNN and MSNBC, they didn't take the arraignment for the suspect because they've believed that's not news, I guess. He has a private attorney. I was wondering who is paying for that. But also, how did he get through? I've read different stories. Did he -- did they do e- verify on him? Did he have a fake ID?

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Yeah. It's saying that -- like the farm owner says that he went through e-verify. He turned over completely cooperate to turn over all the documents. And then DHS, NHL, ICE, they're looking at it to see what happened with e-verify. This guy has been in the country forever. And he murdered a beautiful young girl. From being in a courtroom my entire career, that's who everybody in this country should be focusing on, that victim's parents, her family. Can you imagine what they're going through?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I know, it's unimaginable. And we've talked about families being separated. That's separation. I want to run, Juan, for you, some tapes from Elizabeth Warren. She was talking about this case, lamenting the crime, but then inserting a but.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, D-MASS.
utterances.utterance: I'm so sorry for the family here. And I know this is hard, not only for the family, but for the people in her community, the people throughout Iowa. But, one of the things we have to remember is we need an immigration system that is effective, that focuses on where real problems are.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, Juan, I guess this isn't a real problem that this young woman was murdered?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: No. That's -- I mean, you set it up as so prejudicial to our audience here. I mean, the clear fact of what happened is just horrible to this young woman. But it's also reminds me of the case, Steinle case, where her brother, Brad, came forward and said that he thought Trump was sensationalizing the death of a beautiful young woman. Why would her brother, why would Kate Steinle's brother say that? Because what you see is that people use this for their own purpose. And Trump's case, he's using this to distract and to deceive people in terms of the big news of the day, which is about the Michael Cohen plea deal, about Paul Manafort being convicted. I mean, at this point, you have the president's personal lawyer, his campaign chairman, his national security advisor, all convicted felons. And, oh, no, instead, we want to talk about a murder. Well, there're lots of murders in America. There's a lower rate of violent crime among illegal immigrants and immigrants than there is among native- born Americans.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Guess what? There're some people who say let's not talk about Trump because it's bad news. Like, Trump -- let's talk about this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The point is essential, like there may be more people that are killed texting while driving. So, let's not pay attention to drunk driving. We can exactly tackle both, Juan.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Juan -- I think Juan wants to distract from.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I just want talk about the news of the day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Which we did and we are.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And we're already talking about the Cohen and Manafort case in the B block. Now we're leading the show with this story. So, it seems like you're the one that's trying to distract.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. Well, we're leading with the story about one woman's death.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You just sounded like the professor. There's some one woman.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Just one woman.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Just a girl in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The presidency of the United States, Jesse, is imperiled by these decisions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, according to you. But you know who's really imperiled? Mollie. Now let me just say something, what happened here was horrible and my heart goes out to the family. There's two levels to the story, I think. One, how many dead people are we going to tolerate in this country without solving the immigration problem? We have to have stricter borders. We can't have sanctuary. And we have to do something where you have to be able to verify the people that are in here. Now, on the other hand, the media does not report these stories honestly. And if you look at this one and the other ones that you've mentioned up there, they're misinforming the audience. They're not informing. I looked at that story about the arrest, about the guy driving his wife. And you had to read six paragraphs down to find out that he was wanted for a homicide beef. Now, that would seem like something that would lead and actually be in the headline, but they don't - - they don't inform their viewers. And they're doing the same thing. Now that it's found out that this person is allegedly here illegally, this has now dropped off the top row of a lot of cable news networks and a lot of newspapers. And it's a shame because the American people need to understand the facts about these things so they can elect politicians who can then solve problems.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, let me just say, I don't think there's any correlation between illegal immigration and violent crime in our country, but you make that connection. I don't think it's fair. To me, you know, what's interesting is if there was a mass murderer yesterday, all you guys would be saying, you know, this is not the time to talk about gun control. Let's not do that. That's what the right says. So, here I say, today, and you have one woman who was sadly, tragically killed in Iowa, and you guys want to start talking about immigration.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What happens in this country is that there's tragic events, and then politicians try to lead and try to have solutions. Just like if there was a school shooting, Democrats want to do gun control. Or if there's a hurricane, Democrats want to talk about climate change. I don't blame either side for doing it. That's what politicians do.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, you do. In fact, you sit here and say this is not the time to talk about gun control in the aftermath of a mass murder, but now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not every mass murder.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think the lesson here is we have a broken system that needs fixing. A fix-them, is a like to call.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, a fix-them. It needs to be fixed. I guess they claimed that they were wrong. He didn't get e-verify. That's what I'm learning.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a different type of system is that what you verify. One thing about -- there's -- Lamar Smith has a legislation in front of congress right now, his e-verify system would add that you would be notified if your social security number was put through the system so that you could say, wait, hold on, like, I'm actually here. My social security number is being used.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: And that's why e-verify should be mandatory. And, you know, as a prosecutor, when you're in the courtroom every day for years dealing with victims, you look at -- the only way you can cope is looking at it one victim at a time, and how can we prevent more young girls, boys from being murdered? And that's why this is an important dialogue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Excellent. OK, we've got to move on. Donald Trump hammering his former attorney, Michael Cohen, I wonder why? New reaction from the president, next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: After blasting his former attorney on twitter, President Trump now saying he did not order Michael Cohen to make hush money payments.

utterances.speaker: AINSLEY EARHARDT, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Did you know about the payments?

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Later on I knew. Later on. But you have to understand is, like, what he did, and they weren't taken out of campaign finance. That's a big thing. That's a much bigger thing. Did they come out of the campaign? They didn't come out of the campaign. They came from me. It's not even a campaign violation. If you look at President Obama, he had a massive campaign violation, but he had a different attorney general and they viewed it a lot different.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And that exclusive interview airs tomorrow on Fox & Friends. Meanwhile, Cohen's lawyer, longtime Clinton ally, Lanny Davis, is on a media blitz making new allegations against the President, while also trying to raise money for his client's legal fees.

utterances.speaker: LANNY DAVIS, MICHAEL COHEN'S ATTORNEY
utterances.utterance: He directed Mr. Cohen to make those hush money payments is a federal crime. And if Michael Cohen, with the prosecutors in New York agreeing, admitted to that, then certainly, Donald Trump is guilty of the same crime. Mr. Cohen has knowledge on certain subjects that should be of interest to the special counsel. And is more than happy to tell the special counsel all that he knows. He needs help for himself and his family, and the Michael Cohen truthfund.com go to site is for the American people who want to help.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. More go-fund-me pages. All right, Juan, you've seem like you've been chomping at the bit to tackle this issue. Let it rip.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I mean, I don't want to rip on anything. I just think it's a sad day, and you've got to wonder what's going on when the president is out there saying that Paul Manafort is a brave man, then it raises the question, oh, so he thinks Paul Manafort, who just, you know, been convicted on eight counts and faces 80 years in jail, a convicted felon, all of a sudden, he's a brave man. So, is he thinking about pardoning this man? Oh, because it's politically convenient and he knows Paul Manafort who was his campaign. And then you think, oh, he's out there damning Michael Cohen because he thinks Cohen may have additional facts that could be problematic for this president. It looks so awful that the President of the United States is in this position, and has put himself in this position, and surrounded himself, Jesse, I do this just to tease you, with the very best people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Only the best.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Only the best.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Paul and Michael. Dana, I think when he was saying he's brave, he meant that -- he's looking at, probably, the rest of his life in prison, and he's not going to make up some phony story to satisfy prosecutors out of thin air. I think that's what he was talking about.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, thank you for helping with that. This is how I might have said it, which is I appreciated what he did for me on my campaign. I feel bad for his family that they're going through this. He has been convicted by a jury of his peers under our judicial system, and he's going to have to pay the price for that. Moving on. Like, you don't need to try to make him a synthetic character. He was stealing from the American people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When I do something wrong, I'm going to have you write my tweets.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Which could be any day now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Can I represent you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No. You'll be my.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Are you kidding? I would be a tiger for you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What's so funny because Lanny was the one with the Clinton team that set up this dossier in motion, and then got Cohen on the radar and that's when everybody started looking into him -- you know, hasn't been paying his taxes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm still in that world of I don't care. I mean, this stuff happened before Trump took office, so it's not an impeachable offense. You can't indict a sitting president. So why is this happening? It's just a mess with the guy. That's all this is. This is all about the election and undoing an election, and anger. It's really selective prosecution because there are people like this in Hillary's orbit. You can believe that for a fact.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She had been on the hook is she had won

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, exactly. I mean, how did she pay for that dossier? I don't know. Did she declare it? (INAUDIBLE) I don't know. What about Harvey Weinstein? If she had won, would the Me Too -- would we have known about Harvey Weinstein? Of course not. All of that stuff would have been buried. So let's face it. We're not dealing with angels. But I've moved beyond that. I don't care if they're not angels. I don't care about the lawyers. Trump is not the greatest husband, you know. Stormy has really given porn stars a bad name. She -- when you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's such a good name to.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The only thing she's doing is she's just mad she didn't get more money out of a deal that she's now reneging on.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Right, agree there about giving porn stars a bad name. But in the real world, this happens all the time, OK? CEO's, millionaires, they get extorted all the time. All the time. And they often -- I've been called about it, what do I do? And I say report it to the police. Most of them don't want to report it. So what's their next option? Go to a civil lawyer. And that's what a non-lawyer, Donald Trump did. He went to an attorney. He could have given her cash. He could have paid her off. He went to an attorney and said fix this legally. And this is on Michael Cohen. This is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Legally?

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Sure. Sure, you can sign a nondisclosure. You can sign -- this happens all the time in the real business world. You can sign a nondisclosure. You can make a payment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: With campaign money?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's the problem.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: No, but that's it. But.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's the problem.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: . it's where the money came from. That is on the lawyer. A bad lawyer does not equal.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: . that's what he went to his lawyer.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But we have a tape, Pam. A tape in which the president is discussing this with Michael Cohen.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: And Cohen should have told him you cannot use campaign funds.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They thought you were on one of those tapes, didn't they?

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Isn't it funny? So I listened to it and they've said it was inaudible and I've said, he said Pam. I've heard that, it was Pam. I don't think it's me because I didn't do anything in South Carolina.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was Pam Dauber from Mork and Mindy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think what the president is saying is that these were personal funds that he used to, I guess, pass through a lawyer to have this woman sign an NDA, and it was a personal matter. Maybe it did affect the campaign, but the primary reason was to settle it to not cause any harm to the marriage, or not to cause any bad publicity, or just to get it out of the way because she'd been asking for money for quite some time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: If it turns out that it is from his own personal checkbook and it didn't go through the campaign, then maybe he's got a point. But I don't see how the prosecutors could have gotten Cohen to plead guilty for something if it was not actually campaign money.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And what about the money for the National Enquirer? That came - - that was from the National Enquirer to, I think, Karen McDougal who is the Playboy model.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did you think -- because, you know, Andrew McCarthy had a great piece in the National Review.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow. We've been quoting him all week.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Where he was saying -- probably bringing the pain on these other tax charges and saying you're looking at a lot of time, you know. Why don't you plead to these lesser kind of campaign violations.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Possibly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's a thinner case.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Possible. But then, also, and I don't know anything about this one either, but now Cohen has another subpoena.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . about the Trump foundation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, I mean, he's in a situation where he's in a downward spiral.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, they're going after him big time. And I think I agree with Greg. It's to avenge Hillary's loss and to bring a lot of heartbreak on the president.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: And he's useful to the criminal prosecution, unless they have other credible evidence because he's told so many stories.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, his credibility is shot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: One thing to note, for the longest time we've been saying Trump has a thin skin. He's got a pretty thick hide to do his job while this is going on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that's tough. Tough day. More tough days ahead, I'm sure. The anti-Trump media ramping up impeachment talk, again, after these developments. That's ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The media revs up the push to impeach President Trump, this follows Michael Cohen's guilty plea. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You now have the President of the United States accused of committing a federal crime. The way a functional Washington would work is that congress -- there's a process here. The judiciary committee and the House of Representatives will begin to look to see if there's enough evidence to start investigating and drawing up articles of impeachment.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Should the president be more worried about impeachment than before because of what have happened today?

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Are we in impeachment territory here?

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Today, the Trump presidency took a giant step toward impeachment.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, the question is, is the media sort of salivating, especially left-wing media, or is there justification for this, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think -- I feel that they're hoping that this story can keep going because there's not that much else actually going on in August. They would like to see impeachment. Guess who doesn't want to see impeachment talk? Pelosi, Schumer, like leading Democrats who are saying please do not try to suggest this because you will overplay your hand. And if you want to encourage Republicans to get out and vote in the midterms, you will keep on this nonsense about impeachment. I saw one Democrat suggest forget impeachment, go for the indictment, even though there's this -- you can't indict a sitting president. Some people think that that is an open question that should be taken to the Supreme Court. Regardless, I think, impeachment, it's going to be impossible for them to stop talking about it completely, but I think maybe there'll be a bat signal to all the Democrats to cool it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Pam, you're the lawyer sitting here with us today, so tell us. Can you indict a sitting president? And, if not, is impeachment a legitimate alternative?

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: If it's a legitimate case, of course. And that's probably what Mueller is looking in putting together now, an impeachment memo, which congress.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Or not.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: . would love. Or possibly, right. But I don't feel they have enough to do it. We all know it's super high standard. You know, you've got to have a majority of the house, and then it goes to the senate. Two- thirds. It's not going to happen. And because of what I said earlier, you know, you cannot link the president back to this. First of all, it has nothing to do with Russia. You've got some guy, Michael Cohen, saying I'd take a bullet for Trump. Then next, he's going after the President of the United States. So he has zero credibility. They would have to have credible, substantial, independent information to corroborate anything Cohen says. I think, like you said, for Mueller to even write an impeachment memo, it's just not there. And they just can't go forward with it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But, Jesse, yesterday in court, Cohen said that Trump instructed him to violate the law, and Cohen said this publicly in open court, right? And, apparently, then the question becomes, is the president an unindicted coconspirator, should, at least, the congress be looking at this and saying, gee, the president looks to have been named as having committed a felony?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's their prerogative. They can look at whatever they want to look at. I don't know if I trust Michael Cohen that much. He's facing a lot of hard time. And it's a he said-he said. So let the chips fall where they will. Two-thirds of the senate -- all this is, is a talking point for the Democrats. And they do win the house, there may be a move to impeach. And to say, you know, we're going to run in 2020 against an impeached incumbent gives the Democrats some, you know, political credibility there. And it's harmful to the president, I think, politically to be impeached. But, you know, it will also, maybe, hurt the economy a little bit and undermine his credibility as the commander-in-chief when he goes abroad. But, I just don't see it happening. Independents don't believe this is a high crime. Republicans, obviously, don't believe this is an impeachable offense. I don't think there's an appetite in the country for this. The story is probably going to fizzle out in a few days. And the Democrats, with Maxine Waters, are going to have a hard time keeping lid on these feisty, you know, far left people on the far left and it's going to be a real headache for the leadership, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
